abstract.p: Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation has published list of contractors and other professionals in restoration, which it says is first and only such publication in the state (S)

block.p: The Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation has come to the rescue of Connecticut parishioners searching for a church-steeple repairman -- and everyone else who needs to find help to do restoration work.

As a guide to homeowners and others concerned with the preservation of old buildings, the trust has published a list of contractors and other professionals in restoration, which it says is the first and only such publication in the state.

The Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation has come to the rescue of Connecticut parishioners searching for a church-steeple repairman -- and everyone else who needs to find help to do restoration work.

As a guide to homeowners and others concerned with the preservation of old buildings, the trust has published a list of contractors and other professionals in restoration, which it says is the first and only such publication in the state.

It gives the names and a descriptive paragraph on such specialists as building movers, historic-preservation consultants, millworkers, cabinetmakers, antiques and stained-glass restorers -- and church steeple restorers.

The trust says that it receives hundreds of telephone calls every year from people who have such questions as ''Who can help me restore a crumbling 18th-century chimney?'' and ''Should I use vinyl siding to replace my cracked clapboard?'' The directory will presumably forestall these phone calls.
The directory costs $10 ($7.50 for trust members) plus shipping costs.
The trust can be reached by telephone at (203) 562-6312, by fax at (203) 773-0107 or by e-mail at directory@cttrust.org.
